Posts.Content: Jun 8, 2017 01:03PM LoriBach wrote: I was just wondering how many were diagnosed with a recurrence, but did not have any obvious symptoms? I went to the MO the other day for some swelling in my neck. He said it was nothing cause he could not feel any lymph nodes. Blood work was run and my CEA and CA 29-29 came back elevated as well as my liver tests came back higher than usual. None of the numbers are extreme, just above the range (except for the CEA). Having a Pet scan done. Anyone experience similar?
Posts.Title: If you are not Stage IV but have questions, you may post here chrissyb Olma61
If you are not Stage IV but have questions, you may post here chrissyb Olma61

Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2019 01:24AM LoriBach wrote: I have a question... was anyone's recurrence initially discovered via increased tumor markers (CA 27-29 or CEA)? My CA-27-29 jumped from 31 to 67 and my CEA jumped from 1.1 to 11.8. I am having scans later this week.
Posts.Title: If you are not Stage IV but have questions, you may post here chrissyb Olma61

Posts.Content: Mar 6, 2019 04:52AM LoriBach wrote: Thanks everyone for responding. My tumor markers have been consistent for over 6 years. I have them checked every 6 mos. My CA 27-29 was 41 when I was diagnosed stage 2b with lymphatic invasion. It has always hovered between 31 and 35. Once it went to 39 when they changed labs. My CEA has never gone past 4. When I was in for my 6 mo appointment, I was asking him what early lung mets felt like. I have had a slight pain in my lungs and a funky cough, mostly at night. He didn't think it sounded like anything to worry about. Then two days later he calls which he has never done in all our years together, The CEA worries me more than the CA 27-29.
Posts.Title: If you are not Stage IV but have questions, you may post here chrissyb Olma61

Posts.Content: Mar 7, 2019 07:00AM LoriBach wrote: Brain MRI clear... now we wait to have pet scan on Friday.

Posts.Content: Jun 14, 2013 11:00AM LoriBach wrote: 1)  I agree with the PTSD.  This by far has been the hardest for me.  I cannot get the cancer out of mind and the fear of its return.  Unless you have been through it, you just don't get it. 2) I wish I had put the into finding a plastic surgeon who was a better communicator earlier.  I just kept thinking - well he is a good surgeon, I can find out what I need to know on the web.  Wrong... you need a PS who is both a good communicator as well as good surgeon!
Posts.Title: What I wished I had known.... PeggySull sciencegal

Posts.Content: Apr 25, 2014 03:08PM LoriBach wrote: Don't even get me started on the weight gain...
Posts.Title: ARRGGH, Amy Robach kebab tangandchris

Posts.Content: Apr 25, 2014 03:02PM LoriBach wrote: I agree with everything everybody is saying.  The perception is that caught early, means cured.  My friends and family do not understand why I worry about recurrence.  They think we just need to get to the 5 year mark.  Sadly unless you've experienced mets personally or researched it, you don't know.  It is not talked about and if it is, they tell you the risk is so small.  I have lost a couple of friends to BC.  The risk is very real.  Instead of promoting early detection... lets use those funds to research why it metastisizes in some and not in others. P.S.  It kills me that Amy didn't loose her hair.  I am 17 mos out from chemo and my hair still has not grown in to the point where I do not need a wig.
Posts.Title: ARRGGH, Amy Robach kebab tangandchris

Posts.Content: May 15, 2013 05:09PM LoriBach wrote: I know the feeling.  But to answer your question...yes.  At this point you are believed to be cancer free.  The purpose of the chemo / rads is to insure there were no microscopic escapees and if there were, they will be destroyed.
